docs.lead_paragraph: Oscar De La Hoya plans to make the most of his visit to New York this week, with appearances on television shows. But Felix Trinidad, who took away De La Hoya's World Boxing Council welterweight title in a controversial decision last September, will try to steal some of the spotlight. De La Hoya is in town for his welterweight bout against Derrell Coley on Saturday night at Madison Square Garden. The 12-round match will be televised on HBO's Championship Boxing series. Trinidad will hold a workout at the Church Street Gym in lower Manhattan this afternoon in preparation for his bout with David Reid, the World Boxing Association superwelterweight champion, on March 3 in Las Vegas.
docs.abstract: Oscar De La Hoya will fight Derrell Coley in welterweight bout at Madison Square Garden on Feb 26 (S)

headline.main: De La Hoya Takes the Town

docs.snippet: A crisis of confidence had struck the resident of the big cedar log cabin at the corner of De La Hoya Street and Golden Boy Avenue in this mountain resort town three hours east of Los Angeles. It clung to him like a sweat-soaked T-shirt before, du...
docs.lead_paragraph: A crisis of confidence had struck the resident of the big cedar log cabin at the corner of De La Hoya Street and Golden Boy Avenue in this mountain resort town three hours east of Los Angeles. It clung to him like a sweat-soaked T-shirt before, during and immediately after his loss to Felix Trinidad last September, the first loss of his professional career. But in the past six weeks it has dissolved into the pools of sweat in the makeshift boxing gym that he set up in the four-car garage that is 50 feet from the main house. It drifted away slowly, like the puffs of his frosty breath as he tortured his mind and body running the steep trails in the San Bernardino Mountains above his house.
docs.abstract: Oscar De La Hoya, former World Boxing Council welterweight champion, will fight Derrell Coley in 12-round bout at Madison Square Garden; it will be his first fight in New York since he leveled Jesse James Leija five years ago; photo (M)

Overall, it's the mood, sensibility and lifestyle of these films that I find inspirational. It is not so much about the clothes as it is about the honesty and passion of the personal relationships portrayed. Like Jimmy Stewart's character in 'Mr. Smith Goes to Washington' -- his personal conviction and honor inspired me. In fashion, trends change from year to year, and it takes a lot to be true to yourself. So when I see a character that struggles to remain true, I remember it. In 'Chariots of Fire,' the clothes even look like Ralph Lauren. But what really inspired me was the drive and integrity of those young runners.'' Ralph Lauren supports the Telluride Film Festival. The beige-on-beige sets and costumes are breathtaking, and the emotional vacuum is Allen at his best.'' Once Were Warriors (Lee Tamahori, 1994) ''This film blows me away. I always feel completely depleted and defeated after watching it. docs.lead_paragraph: ''If I had Oscar De La Hoya everyone would know who I am,'' Cedric Kushner said wistfully. His sad eyes and hangdog gray mustache furthered the sense of deprivation; De La Hoya fights Derrell Coley on Saturday night at Madison Square Garden and poor Cedric, like you and me, won't have a piece of the action. But two nights earlier, just across the street from the Garden, he will offer up his version of boxing, so retrograde, so socially incorrect, so true to the sport's intrinsic character that its time has probably come yet again. It is a monthly evening of booze, food, cigars, songs, scantily clad women dancing and scantily clad men hitting each other.

docs.lead_paragraph: Movie stars! There's something kitschy in the term -- actors and actresses appearing as constellations in the firmament. Only, unlike Perseus and Cassiopeia, movie stars do not have places assured for millenniums. Each year an Oort Cloud of starlets streaks across our consciousness and fades without a trace. Some faces still shine, however, across tens, if not thousands, of years. These are the ones whose images are archetypes: Katharine Hepburn, the independent woman; Jean Harlow, the platinum seductress; Joan Crawford, the manipulative schemer. More often than not, their looks, and even their personalities, were forged at Max Factor's makeup factory and dream shop near the corner of Hollywood and Highland. This was where Harlow was made platinum, where the brunette Rita Cansino was reinvented as the fiery redhead Rita Hayworth, and where Joan Crawford's mouth was painted with aloof indifference to the line of her lips.

docs.lead_paragraph: STOCKARD CHANNING OWNS THE ROLE OF THE BRITTLE Ouisa Kittredge in SIX DEGREES OF SEPARATION (1993). She originated it in John Guare's stage satire, and she plays it in Fred Schepisi's film version (screen-play by Mr. Guare) to the hilt. Donald Sutherland is her art dealer husband. Will Smith is the young man who turns up at their elegant apartment needing assistance, claiming to be Sidney Poitier's son, offering them roles in the movie version of ''Cats'' and generally charming them to death. No, it's not as remarkable on screen as it was at Lincoln Center 10 years ago, but the style and bite remain - Sunday at 9 p.m., Sunday/Early Monday at 1 a.m., Monday at 1 p.m., Saturday at 8 p.m. and Saturday/Early Sunday at 12:30 a.m. on Bravo.

docs.snippet: LUIS BUNUEL was born 100 years ago, and, for many of us, finding his work was like holding a key to our dreams. We were seeing strange, yet strangely serene things. They were violent, outrageous even, but was there any need to be shocked? We knew ...
docs.lead_paragraph: LUIS BUNUEL was born 100 years ago, and, for many of us, finding his work was like holding a key to our dreams. We were seeing strange, yet strangely serene things. They were violent, outrageous even, but was there any need to be shocked? We knew his films had an inner meaning that was for us to puzzle out. That elusive meaning can depend on how you describe what occurred; on whether you believe you are the protagonist in the drama of yourself -- or someone being dreamed in another's sleep. In the former, the mood is likely to be filled with significance and grandeur. But in the latter, there may be a hint of absurdity or misunderstanding. So you can say that, ''On Feb. 22, 1983, on the occasion of his 83rd birthday, with the great Luis Bunuel in less than certain health, he received the honor of a visit from the president of Mexico.'' Or you could say, ''Bunuel was dying, and the president of Mexico came to congratulate him.'' By July 1983, all such ceremonies were over and Bunuel turned over in his bed and died.

docs.lead_paragraph: An Actor Makes a Splash John Lithgow has appeared before the American public in guises ranging from a football player turned transsexual (the film ''The World According to Garp'') to a space alien masquerading as a physics professor (the sitcom ''Third Rock From the Sun''). But tomorrow he will play what may be his most surprising role: children's entertainer. ''I'm surprised myself,'' Mr. Lithgow said. ''I haven't quite mastered it yet. It's in-service training. I'm learning to sing in front of an orchestra with 2,800 screaming children.'' In the past, Mr. Lithgow has usually elicited screams only when playing a psychopath. Things will be far less scary tomorrow at Carnegie Hall, where he will present a family concert based on his 1999 album, ''Singin' in the Bathtub,'' released by Sony Wonder.
